column1: Astronomy is a natural science. It is the study of everything outside the atmosphere of Earth.It studies celestial objects (such as stars
column6: comets and nebulae) and processes (such as supernovae explosions
column8: and cosmic microwave background radiation). This includes the physics
column9: chemistry of those objects and processes.A related subject
column11: is concerned with studying the Universe as a whole
column12: and the way the universe changed over time.The word astronomy comes from the Greek words astron which means star and nomos which means law. A person who studies astronomy is called an astronomer.Astronomy is one of the oldest sciences. Ancient people used the positions of the stars to navigate
column13: and to find when was the best time to plant crops. Astronomy is very similar to astrophysics. Since the 20th century there have been two main types of astronomy
column14: observational and theoretical astronomy. Observational astronomy uses telescopes and cameras to observe or look at stars
column15: galaxies and other astronomical objects. Theoretical astronomy uses maths and computer models to predict what should happen.
